page.title: 6.2.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative


This lesson continues to explore operations with polynomials as students master polynomial multiplication. Students start by multiplying with monomials. This involves a review of the properties of exponents and the Distributive Property. Multiple methods are then introduced to practice multiplying two binomials.

The previously introduced Vertical Alignment and distribution will be used to multiply polynomials by other polynomials. As students learn these methods better, they will weigh their advantages and disadvantages. They will learn to recognize special situations in which patterns can be learned and implemented to efficiently multiply these binomials together. Finally, students will use their previous knowledge of polynomial functions to further practice the multiplication they have learned in this lesson.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Multiply monomials together using multiplication properties of exponents.
  • Multiply polynomials together using the Distributive Property, Vertical Alignment, and the FOIL method (for binomials).
  • Recognize special case products such as binomial squares and conjugate pairs and use designated rules to facilitate their multiplication.
  • Multiply polynomials expressed in function form.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Multiply monomials.
  • Multiply a polynomial by a monomial.
  • Multiply binomials.
  • Multiply a polynomial by a polynomial.
  • Multiply special products.
  • Multiply polynomial functions.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A10(B) multiply polynomials of degree one and degree two;

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 6.2.1: Multiplying Monomials
  • 6.2.2: Multiplying Binomials
    • 6.2.2: Self Check
    • 6.2.2: Additional Resources
  • 6.2.3: Multiplying a Polynomial by a Polynomial
    • 6.2.3: Self Check
    • 6.2.3: Additional Resources
  • 6.2.4: Multiplying Special Products
    • 6.2.4: Self Check
    • 6.2.4: Additional Resources
  • 6.2.5: Multiplying Polynomial Functions

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 6.2.6: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Paper and pencil

Required Preparation

  • None

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • monomial
  • binomial
  • trinomial
  • polynomial
  • polynomial function
  • conjugate pair
  • difference of squares

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their judgment.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • Fundamental Beliefs
  • Reserve Judgment

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Judgment from Character Lab.

page.title: 6.2.1: Multiplying Monomials
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)

This warm-up reviews how to use the Commutative Property and properties of exponents to multiply monomials. Review how the properties of exponents determine how we multiply terms together. Before assigning the individual exercises, ask students how the Distributive Property will determine how to multiply the monomial by the expression in parentheses.

Launch

Solve the first two examples as a class to demonstrate multiplying monomials. Review the solutions provided. Then allow students to solve the following problems individually.

Student Activity

Since monomials are algebraic expressions, we can use the properties of exponents to multiply monomials.

Multiply the monomials.

  1. \( (3x^2)(-4x^3)\)

ANSWER:
Step 1
Use the Commutative Property to rearrange the terms.
\(3\cdot(−4)\cdot x^2\cdot x^3\)

Step 2
Multiply.
\(−12x^5\)

  1. \((\frac56x^3y)(12xy^2)\)

ANSWER:
Step 1
Use the Commutative Property to rearrange the terms.
\(\frac56\cdot12\cdot x^3\cdot x\cdot y\cdot y^2\)

Step 2
Multiply.
\(10x^4y^3\)

Multiplying a polynomial by a monomial is done by applying the Distributive Property of Multiplication over Addition.

Find the product of each expression.

  1. \(7x(3x+6)\)

ANSWER: \(21x^2+42x\)

  1. \(7b^2(9b-4)\)

ANSWER: \(63b^3-28b^2\)

  1. \(2k(5k^2+3k-1)\)

ANSWER: \(10k^3+6k^2-2k\)

  1. \(4r^2s(2r^2+8rs-12s^2)\)

ANSWER: \(8r^4s+32r^3s^2-48r^2s^3\)

Activity Synthesis

Review these key concepts from the activity with students:

  • Remind students that when multiplying monomials together, the individual factors can be written out in a larger multiplication expression. The Commutative Property allows the terms to be rearranged so that appropriate terms can be combined.
  • The properties of exponents say that when multiplying exponential values with the same base, the base remains the same and the exponents are added together.
  • To distribute a value through an expression in parentheses, the value is multiplied by each term in the parentheses.

page.title: 6.2.2: Multiplying Binomials
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity introduces three different ways to multiply binomials together. Students should familiarize themselves with each method. Then they can decide which method works best for them and use the others to check their multiplication.

Launch

As a class, examine the three methods used in the table to multiply \((x-7)(2x+4)\). Go step by step through each method while asking for questions after each method. Then allow students to work through the exercises individually.

Student Activity

The binomials in the expression \((x-7)(2x+4)\) are solved three different ways in the table. Describe how the two binomials are being multiplied.


Solution

Description of Solution

\((x-7)(2x+4)\)

\(x(2x+4)-7(2x+4)\)

\(2x^2+4x-14x-28\)

\(2x^2-10x-28\)

First, ______________________.

Second, ___________________.

Next, ___________________.

So, the solution is \(2x^2-10x-28\).

\(\underline{\underline{\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x-7\\\times\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;2x+4}\\\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;4x-28\\\;\;2x^2-14x}\\\;\;2x^2-10x-28\)

First, ______________________.

Second, ___________________.

Third, ____________________.

Next, ___________________.

So, the solution is \(2x^2-10x-28\).

\(2x^2+4x-14x-28\)

\(2x^2-10x-28\)

First, ______________________.

Second, ___________________.

Third, ____________________.

Next, ___________________.

Combine like terms, and the solution is \(2x^2-10x-28\).

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

ANSWER:


Solution

Description of Solution

\((x-7)(2x+4)\)

\(x(2x+4)-7(2x+4)\)

\(2x^2+4x-14x-28\)

\(2x^2-10x-28\)

First, the second binomial \((2x + 4)\) is distributed to both of the terms in the first binomial.

Second, individual terms are distributed.

Next, the like terms \(4x\) and \( –14x\) are combined.

So, the solution is \(2x^2-10x-28\).

\(\underline{\underline{\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x-7\\\times\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;2x+4}\\\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;4x-28\\\;\;2x^2-14x}\\\;\;2x^2-10x-28\)

First, the binomials are written vertically.

Second, the last term of the bottom binomial is multiplied, or distributed, to each of the terms in the top binomial.

Third, the first term of the bottom binomial is multiplied, or distributed, to each of the terms in the top binomial, being sure to line up the like terms vertically.

Next, add the like terms. They should be “stacked” on top of each other.

So, the solution is \(2x^2-10x-28\).

\(2x^2+4x-14x-28\)

\(2x^2-10x-28\)

First, distribute the first term of the front binomial to the first term of the back binomial (F).

Second, distribute the first term of the front binomial to the second term of the back binomial (O).

Third, distribute the second term of the front binomial to the first term of the back binomial (I).

Next, distribute the second term of the front binomial to the second term of the back binomial (L).

Combine like terms, and the solution is \(2x^2-10x-28\).

Multiply each binomial expression.

  1. \((a+6)(a-4)\)

ANSWER: \(a^2+2a-24\)

  1. \((5b+9)(4b+3)\)

ANSWER: \(20b^2+51b+27\)

  1. \((5x^2-1)(2x-8)\)

ANSWER: \(10x^3-40x^2-2x+8\)

  1. \((7mn+1)(11mn-3)\)

ANSWER: \(77m^2n^2-10mn-3\)

Student-Facing Extension

Are you ready for more?

Multiply the binomials. Add like terms to simplify the expression.

\((5x^2y-xy)(3x+y)+(6x+4y)(-3x^2y+2xy)\)

ANSWER:
\((5x^2y-xy)(3x+y)+(6x+4y)(-3x^2y+2xy)\)

\(\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;=15x^3y+5x^2y^2-3x^2y-xy^2-18x^3y+12x^2y-12x^2y^2+8xy^2\)

\(\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;=-3x^3y+9x^2y-7x^2y^2+7xy^2\)

Anticipated Misconceptions

When students use the Distributive Property, emphasize that the sign combining the new products is determined by the sign in the binomial that is broken up. The example from the table is shown below, with the corresponding signs in red:

\((x\;{\style{color:red}-}\;7)(2x+4) = x(2x+4)\;{\style{color:red}-}\;7(2x+4)\)

Activity Synthesis

Ask students to explain which method they prefer. As students discuss each method, emphasize the following points:

  • To use the Distributive Property, the first binomial is broken up so that each term is multiplied by the second binomial.
  • When using Vertical Alignment, it is important to align like terms as you write the individual products. This will help you combine them into the correct final product.
  • When using the FOIL method, you can view the process as 4 individual steps that are then combined to find the product.

6.2.2: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.


QUESTION:

Multiply the binomials.

\((5y+2)(6y-3)\)

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(30y^2-3y-6\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: Confirm your solution by multiplying the binomials a different way. You should find the same solution.

\(27y-6\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Did you multiply the first two terms together to get \(30y^2\)? The answer is \(30y^2-3y-6\).

\(30y^2-27y-6\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Did you use the correct signs when multiplying in each step? The answer is \(30y^2-3y-6\).

\(30y^2+3y+6\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Did you use the correct signs when combining like terms? The answer is \(30y^2-3y-6\).

6.2.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Multiplying Binomials Using the Distributive Property

Just like there are different ways to represent multiplication of numbers, there are several different ways to represent how to multiply a binomial times a binomial using the Distributive Property of Multiplication over Addition.

Distribute to multiply the binomials.

  1. \((y+5)(y+8)\)

Step 1
Distribute the binomial \((y+8)\).

\(y {\style{color:red}( }{\style{color:red}y}\;{\style{color:red}+}\;{\style{color:red}8}{\style{color:red}) }+ 5{\style{color:red}( }{\style{color:red}y}\;{\style{color:red}+}\;{\style{color:red}8}{\style{color:red}) }\)

Step 2
Now, distribute the individual terms.
\(y^2+8y+5y+40\)

Step 3
Combine like terms.
\(y^2+13y+40\)

  1. \((4y+3)(2y-5)\)

Step 1
Distribute the binomial \((2y - 5)\).
\(4y {\style{color:red}( } {\style{color:red}2}{\style{color:red}y}\;{\style{color:red}-}\;{\style{color:red}5}{\style{color:red}) }\;+ 3{\style{color:red}( } {\style{color:red}2}{\style{color:red}y}\;{\style{color:red}-}\;{\style{color:red}5}{\style{color:red}) }\)

Step 2
Now, distribute the individual terms.
\(8y^2-20y+6y-15\)

Step 3
Combine like terms.
\(8y^2-14y-15\)

Multiplying Binomials Using the FOIL Method

If you multiply binomials often enough, you may notice a pattern. Notice that the first term in the result is the product of the first terms in each binomial. The second and third terms are the product of multiplying the two outer terms and then the two inner terms. And the last term results from multiplying the two last terms.

We abbreviate “First, Outer, Inner, Last” as FOIL. The letters stand for “First, Outer, Inner, Last.” We use this as another way to multiply binomials. The word FOIL is easy to remember and ensures we find all four products.

Let’s multiply \((x+3)(x+7)\) using both methods.

We summarize the steps of the FOIL method below. The FOIL method only applies to multiplying binomials, not other polynomials!

How to use the FOIL method to multiply two binomials:

Step 1
Multiply the First terms.

Step 2
Multiply the Outer terms.

Step 3
Multiply the Inner terms.

Step 4
Multiply the Last terms.

Step 5
Combine like terms, when possible.


When you multiply by the FOIL method, drawing the arrows will help your brain focus on the pattern and make it easier to apply.

Now we will review examples where we use the FOIL pattern to multiply two binomials.

Multiply the binomials using the FOIL method.

  1. \((y-7)(y+4)\)

Step 1
Multiply the \({\style{color:red}F}{\style{color:red}i}{\style{color:red}r}{\style{color:red}s}{\style{color:red}t}\) terms.

Step 2
Multiply the \({\style{color:red}O}{\style{color:red}u}{\style{color:red}t}{\style{color:red}e}{\style{color:red}r}\) terms.

Step 3
Multiply the \({\style{color:red}I}{\style{color:red}n}{\style{color:red}n}{\style{color:red}e}{\style{color:red}r}\) terms.

Step 4
Multiply the \({\style{color:red}L}{\style{color:red}a}{\style{color:red}s}{\style{color:red}t}\) terms.

Step 5
Combine like terms.
\(y^2 - 3y - 28\)

  1. \((4x-3)(2x-5)\)

Step 1
Multiply the First terms, \( {\style{color:red}4} {\style{color:red}x} \; {\style{color:red}\cdot} \; {\style{color:red}2} {\style{color:red}x} \).

Step 2
Multiply the Outer terms, \( {\style{color:red}4} {\style{color:red}x}\; {\style{color:red}\cdot}\; {\style{color:red}(} {\style{color:red}{-5}} {\style{color:red})} \).

Step 3
Multiply the Inner terms, \( {\style{color:red}3}\; {\style{color:red}\cdot}\; {\style{color:red}2} {\style{color:red}x} \).

Step 4
Multiply the Last terms, \( {\style{color:red}3}\; {\style{color:red}\cdot}\; {\style{color:red}(} {\style{color:red}{-5}} {\style{color:red})} \).

Step 5
Combine like terms.
\(8x^2-14x-15\)

The FOIL method is usually the quickest method for multiplying two binomials, but it only works for binomials. You can use the Distributive Property to find the product of any two polynomials.

Multiplying Binomials Using Vertical Alignment

Another representation that works for all polynomials is Vertical Alignment. It is much like the method you use to multiply whole numbers. Look carefully at this example of multiplying two-digit numbers.

\(\underline{\underline{\;\;\;\;23\\\times46}\\\;\;138\\\;\;92}\\1058\)

partial product
partial product
product

Start by multiplying 23 by 6 to get 138.
Next, multiply 23 by 4, lining up the partial product in the correct columns.
Finally, add the partial products.

  1. Multiply using Vertical Alignment: \((3y-1)(2y-6)\). It does not matter which binomial goes on the top.

Step 1
Multiply \(3y-1\) by \(-6\).

Step 2
Multiply \(3y-1\) by \(2y\).

Step 3
Add like terms.

Notice the partial products are the same as the terms in the FOIL method.

\(\begin{array}{l}\begin{array}{r}\left(3y-1\right)\left(2y-6\right)\\{ {\style{color:blue}6} {\style{color:blue}y}^ {\style{color:blue}2}\;     {\style{color:blue}-} \;{\style{color:blue}2} {\style{color:blue}y}\;     {\style{color:red}-}\;     {\style{color:red}1} {\style{color:red}8} {\style{color:red}y}\;     {\style{color:red}+} \;{\style{color:red}6} }\\\hline{6y^2-20y+6}\end{array}\end{array}\)

We have now used three ways to multiply binomials. Be sure to practice each process, and try to decide which one you prefer.

Try It: Multiplying Binomials

Multiply the binomials using any of the methods described.

  1. \((x+8)(x+9)\)

  2. \((3c^2+4)(5c-2)\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to multiply the binomials:


  1. Using the Distributive Property by distributing either a binomial or an individual term:

    \((x+8)(x+9)\)
    \(x(x+9)+8(x+9)\)
    \(x^2+9x+8x+72\)
    \(x^2+17x+72\)

    Using FOIL:

    \((x+8)(x+9)\)

    \(x^2+9x+8x+72\)
    F        O       I         L

    \(x^2+17x+72\)

    Using Vertical Alignment:

    \(\underline{\underline{\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x+8\\\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\times\;x+9}\\\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;9x+72\\ \;\;x^2+8x}\\x^2+17x+72\)


  2. Using the Distributive Property by distributing either a binomial or an individual term:

    \((3c^2+4)(5c-2)\)
    \(3c^2(5c-2)+4(5c-2)\)
    \(15c^3-6c^2+20c-8\)

    Using FOIL:

    \((3c^2+4)(5c-2)\)

    \(15c^3-6c^2+20c-8\)
    F            O          I        L

    \(15c^3-6c^2+20c-8\)

    Using Vertical Alignment:

    \(\underline{\underline{\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;3c^2+4\\\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\times5c-2}\\\;\;\;\;\;\;-6c^2\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;-8\\15c^3\;\;\;\;\;\;\;+20c}\\15c^3-6c^2+20c-8\)

page.title: 6.2.3: Multiplying a Polynomial by a Polynomial
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity reinforces the use of Vertical Alignment and distribution to multiply a binomial by a larger polynomial. Emphasize that the FOIL method will only work when you are multiplying two binomials, not with a trinomial or a larger polynomial.

Launch

Allow students to work individually on the exercises provided. Allow extra time to answer questions as needed.

Student Activity

Match each polynomial expression to its simplified solution. Be prepared to explain or show your work.

  1. \((c+1)(c^2+3c+6)\)
  2. \((c-6)(c^2+c+1)\)
  3. \((c+5)(c^2+2c-4)\)
  4. \( (c-3)(c^2-4c-1)\)
  5. \((c+10)(c^2-5c+2)\)
  1. \(c^3-7c^2+11c+3\)
  2. \(c^3-5c^2-5c-6\)
  3. \(c^3+7c^2+6c-20\)
  4. \( c^3+4c^2+9c+6\)
  5. \(c^3+5c^2-48c+20\)

ANSWERS:

  1. d. \(c^3+4c^2+9c+6\)
  2. b. \(c^3-5c^2-5c-6\)
  3. c. \(c^3+7c^2+6c-20\)
  4. a. \(c^3-7c^2+11c+3\)
  5. e. \(c^3+5c^2-48c+20\)

    6. Now, fill in the missing blanks to complete the polynomial multiplication.

    \(\begin{array}{rcl}\left(2x-4\right)\left(x^2+\square x+5\right)&=&2x\left(x^2+6x-5\right)-4\left(x^2+6x-\square\right)\\&=&2x^3+\square x^2-10x-4x^2-24x+\square\\&=&\square x^3+8x^2-\square x+20\end{array}\)

ANSWER:
\(\begin{array}{rcl}\left(2x-4\right)\left(x^2+6x+5\right)&=&2x\left(x^2+6x-5\right)-4\left(x^2+6x-5\right)\\&=&2x^3+12x^2-10x-4x^2-24x+20\\&=&2x^3+8x^2-34x+20\end{array}\)

Anticipated Misconceptions

If students are struggling with filling in the blanks to complete the polynomial multiplication, encourage them to use what they know about the Distributive Property to complete the first line. The following lines can be found by continuing to solve by distribution.

Activity Synthesis

Ask students to consider the advantages and disadvantages of each method used in the activity. Consider the following:

  • Using Vertical Alignment allows you to align like terms so that they can be easily combined into the final product.
  • How does the time spent using Vertical Alignment compare to the time spent using the Distributive Property?
  • Which method do you find easier to use to double-check your work?

Video: Multiplying Polynomials Using Different Methods

Watch the following video to learn more about how to multiply polynomials using both the Distributive Property and Vertical Alignment.



6.2.3: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.


QUESTION:

Multiply.

\((d+4)(2d^2-3d+5)\)

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(2d^3-11d^2-17d+20\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check the signs of the terms you found when multiplying and combining terms. The answer is \(2d^3+5d^2-7d+20\).

\(2d^3+5d^2-7d+20\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: Use the Distributive Property or Vertical Alignment to check your work.

\(2d^3-3d^2+5d\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is only \((d)(2d^2-3d+5)\). Multiply \(2d^2-3d+5\) by 4 and combine like terms of both parts. The answer is \(2d^3+5d^2-7d+20\).

\(8d^2-12d+20\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is only \((4)(2d^2-3d+5)\). Multiply \(2d^2-3d+5\) by \(d\) and combine like terms of both parts. The answer is \(2d^3+5d^2-7d+20\).

6.2.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Multiplying a Polynomial by a Polynomial

We have multiplied monomials by monomials, monomials by polynomials, and binomials by binomials. Now we’re ready to multiply a polynomial by a polynomial. Remember, FOIL will not work in this case, but we can use other representations of the Distributive Property such as Vertical Alignment or distributing individual terms or polynomials.

Multiply \((b+3)(2b^2-5b+8)\) using:

  1. The Distributive Property by distributing either a binomial or an individual term

Step 1
Distribute \({\style{color:red}(} {\style{color:red}2} {\style{color:red}b} ^ {\style{color:red}2} \;{\style{color:red}-}\;     {\style{color:red}5} {\style{color:red}b}\;     {\style{color:red}+} \;{\style{color:red}8} {\style{color:red})}\).
\(b {\style{color:red}(} {\style{color:red}2} {\style{color:red}b} ^ {\style{color:red}2}\;     {\style{color:red}-}\;     {\style{color:red}5} {\style{color:red}b}\;     {\style{color:red}+}\;     {\style{color:red}8} {\style{color:red})} +3 {\style{color:red}(} {\style{color:red}2} {\style{color:red}b} ^ {\style{color:red}2} \;{\style{color:red}-}\;     {\style{color:red}5} {\style{color:red}b} \;{\style{color:red}+}\;     {\style{color:red}8} {\style{color:red})} \)

Step 2
Multiply.
\(2b^3-5b^2+8b+6b^2-15b+24\)

Step 3
Combine like terms.
\(2b^3+b^2-7b+24\)

  1. Vertical Alignment

It is easier to put the polynomial with fewer terms on the bottom because we get fewer partial products this way.

Step 1
Multiply \((2b^2-5b+8)\) by \(3\).

Step 2
Multiply \((2b^2-5b+8)\) by \(b\).

Step 3
Add like terms.

\(\underline{\underline{\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;2b^2-\;5b+8\\\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\times\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;b+3}\\ \; \\\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;6b^2-15b+24\\2b^3-5b^2\;+8b}\\ \; \\ 2b^3 \; +\;b^2-\;7b+24\)

Try It: Multiplying a Polynomial by a Polynomial

Multiply \((z-3)(z^2-5z+2)\) using:

  1. The Distributive Property

  2. Vertical Alignment

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to multiply the polynomials:

  1. \((z-3)(z^2-5z+2)\)

Step 1
Distribute \((z^2 - 5z + 2)\).
\(z(z^2-5z+2)-3(z^2-5z+2)\)

Step 2
Multiply.
\(z^3-5z^2+2z-3z^2+15z-6\)

Step 3
Combine like terms.
\(z^3-8z^2+17z-6\)



Step 1
Multiply \((z^2-5z+2)\) by \(–3\).

Step 2
Multiply \((z^2-5z+2)\) by \(z\).

Step 3
Add like terms.

\(\underline{\underline{\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;z^2-5z+2\\\;\;\;\;\times\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;z-3}\\ \;\; \\ \;\;\;\;-3z^2+15z-6\\\;z^3-5z^2+2z}\\ \;\; \\z^3-8z^2+17z-6\)

page.title: 6.2.4: Multiplying Special Products
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity prompts students to learn an efficient method to multiply special polynomials. Students will learn to recognize multiplication expressions involving binomial squares and conjugate pairs. They will learn the patterns used to make the multiplication process more efficient than other methods used so far in this lesson.

Launch

Before starting the exercises, ask students to name any polynomial expression that can be identified as a binomial square.

Example of a binomial square: \((x + 3)^2\)

Ask them to name a conjugate pair.

Example of a conjugate pair: \((x - 5)(x + 5)\)

Ask students how to discern between the two different expressions. Then allow students to work through the exercises provided individually.

Student Activity

Multiply each expression. Identify each as a binomial square or a conjugate pair (difference of squares).

  1. \((3x - 7)^2\)

ANSWER: \(9x^2 - 42x + 49\); binomial square

  1. \((6z + 4)(6z - 4)\)

ANSWER: \(36z^2 - 16\); conjugate pair

  1. \((4a + 2b)(4a + 2b)\)

ANSWER: \(16a^2 + 16ab + 4b^2\); binomial square

  1. \( (3w - 9p)(3w + 9p)\)

ANSWER: \(9w^2 - 81p^2\); conjugate pair

  1. \((2y - 8n)(2y + 8n)\)

ANSWER: \(4y^2 - 64n^2\); conjugate pair

  1. \((5k + 2)(5k + 2)\)

ANSWER: \(25k^2 + 20k + 4\); binomial square

Activity Synthesis

Invite a student to name the equation used to identify the multiplication of a binomial square involving addition.

\((a + b)^2 = a^2 + 2ab +b^2\)

Ask another student how the equation involving subtraction is different.

\((a - b)^2 = a^2 - 2ab +b^2\)

Finally, ask a student to name the equation representing the multiplication of conjugate pairs.

\((a +b)(a - b) = a^2 - b^2\)

Ask students how mastering these equations makes multiplying these types of polynomials easier. Tell students that in future lessons, we will work on reversing this process using factoring.

6.2.4: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.


QUESTION:

Multiply.

\((3f - 6g)^2\)

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(9f^2-18fg+36g^2\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: You must multiply the middle term by 2. The correct form for the product of a binomial square is \((a - b)^2 = a^2-2ab+b^2\). The answer is \(9f^2-36fg+36g^2\).

\(9f^2-36fg+36g^2\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: The correct form for the product of a binomial square is \((a - b)^2 = a^2-2ab+b^2\).

\(9f^2-36fg-36g^2\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check the sign on the last term. The correct form for the product of a binomial square is \((a - b)^2 = a^2-2ab+b^2\). The answer is \(9f^2-36fg+36g^2\).

\(9f^2+36g^2\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The middle term is missing. The correct form for the product of a binomial square is \((a - b)^2 = a^2-2ab+b^2\). The answer is \(9f^2-36fg+36g^2\).

Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Multiplying Binomial Squares

Mathematicians like to look for patterns that will make their work easier. A good example of this is squaring binomials. While you can always get the product by writing the binomial twice and multiplying the two binomials, there is less work to do if you learn to use a pattern. Let’s start by looking at three examples and look for a pattern.

Look at these results. Do you see any patterns?

What about the number of terms? In each example, we squared a binomial, and the result was a trinomial.

\((a + b)^2\) = ____ + ____ + ____

Now look at the first term in each result. Where did it come from?

The first term is the product of the first terms of each binomial. Since the binomials are identical, it is just the square of the first term!

\((a + b)^2 = a^2\) + ____ + ____

To get the first term of the product, square the first term.

Where did the last term come from? Look at the examples and find the pattern.

The last term is the product of the last terms, which is the square of the last term.

\((a + b)^2\) = ____ + ____ + \(b^2\)

To get the last term of the product, square the last term.

Finally, look at the middle term. Notice it came from adding the “outer” and the “inner” terms—which are the same! So the middle term is double the product of the two terms of the binomial.

\((a + b)^2\) = ____ \(+ \; 2ab \; +\) ____

\((a + b)^2\) = ____ \(- \; 2ab \; +\) ____

To get the middle term of the product, multiply the terms and double their product.

Putting it all together:

Try It: Multiplying Binomial Squares

Multiply.

  1. \((x + 5)^2\)
  2. \((2x - 3y)^2\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to multiply the binomial squares:

\(\begin{pmatrix} {\style{color:red}a}\; {\style{color:red}+}\; {\style{color:red}b} \\x+5\end{pmatrix}^2\)

Step 1
Square the first term.
\(\begin{array}{c} {\style{color:red}a} ^ {\style{color:red}2}\; {\style{color:red}+}\; {\style{color:red}2} {\style{color:red}a} {\style{color:red}b}\; {\style{color:red}+}\; {\style{color:red}b} ^ {\style{color:red}2} \\x^2+\_\_\_+\_\_\_\end{array}\)

Step 2
Square the last term.
\(\begin{array}{c} {\style{color:red}a} ^ {\style{color:red}2}\; {\style{color:red}+}\; {\style{color:red}2} {\style{color:red}a} {\style{color:red}b}\; {\style{color:red}+}\; {\style{color:red}b} ^ {\style{color:red}2} \\x^2+\_\_\_+5^2\end{array}\)

Step 3
Double the product of the two terms.
\(\begin{array}{c} {\style{color:red}a} ^ {\style{color:red}2}\; {\style{color:red}+}\; {\style{color:red}2}\; {\style{color:red}\cdot}\; {\style{color:red}a}\; {\style{color:red}\cdot}\; {\style{color:red}b}\; {\style{color:red}+}\; {\style{color:red}b} ^ {\style{color:red}2} \\x^2+2\cdot x\cdot5+5^2\end{array}\)

Step 4
Simplify.
\(x^2+10x+25\)

\(\begin{pmatrix} {\style{color:red}a}\; {\style{color:red}-}\; {\style{color:red}b} \\2x-3y\end{pmatrix}^2\)

Step 1
Use the pattern.
\(\begin{array}{c} {\style{color:red}a} ^ {\style{color:red}2}\; {\style{color:red}-}\; {\style{color:red}2}\; {\style{color:red}\cdot}\; {\style{color:red}a}\; {\style{color:red}\cdot}\; {\style{color:red}b}\; {\style{color:red}+}\; {\style{color:red}b} ^ {\style{color:red}2} \\{(2x)}^2-2\cdot2x\cdot3y+{(3y)}^2\end{array}\)

Step 2
Simplify.
\(4x^2-12xy+9y^2\)

Conjugate Pairs

We just saw a pattern for squaring binomials that we can use to make multiplying some binomials easier. Similarly, there is a pattern for another product of binomials.

A pair of binomials that each have the same first term and the same last term, but one is a sum and one is a difference, is called a conjugate pair and is of the form \((a-b)\), \((a+b)\).

CONJUGATE PAIR

A conjugate pair is two binomials of the form

\((a-b),(a+b)\)

The pair of binomials each have the same first term and the same last term, but one binomial is a sum and the other is a difference.


There is a nice pattern for finding the product of conjugates. You could, of course, simply FOIL to get the product, but using the pattern makes your work easier. Let’s look for the pattern by using FOIL to multiply some conjugate pairs.

What do you observe about the products?

The product of the two binomials is also a binomial! Most of the products resulting from FOIL have been trinomials.

Each first term is the product of the first terms of the binomials, and since they are identical, it is the square of the first term.

\((a + b)(a - b) = a^2 -\) ____

To get the first term, square the first term.

The last term came from multiplying the last terms, and it is the square of the last term.

\((a + b)(a - b) = a^2 - b^2\)

To get the last term, square the last term.

Why is there no middle term? Notice the two middle terms you get from FOIL combine to 0 in every case, the result of one addition and one subtraction.

The product of conjugates is always of the form \(a^2 - b^2\). This is called a difference of squares.

This leads to the pattern:

PRODUCT OF CONJUGATES PATTERN

If a and b are real numbers,


We just developed special product patterns for Binomial Squares and for the Product of Conjugates. The products look similar, so it is important to recognize when it is appropriate to use each of these patterns and to notice how they differ. Look at the two patterns together and note their similarities and differences.

COMPARING THE SPECIAL PRODUCT PATTERNS

Binomial Squares

Product of Conjugates

\((a+b)^2=a^2+2ab+b^2\)

\((a-b)(a+b)=a^2-b^2\)

\((a-b)^2=a^2-2ab+b^2\)

 
  • Squaring a binomial.
  • Multiplying conjugates.
  • Product is a trinomial.
  • Product is a binomial.
  • Inner and outer terms with FOIL are the same.
  • Inner and outer terms with FOIL are opposites.
  • Middle term is double the product of the two terms.
  • There is no middle term.

Try It: Conjugate Pairs

Multiply.

  1. \((2x + 5)(2x - 5)\)
  2. \((5m - 9n)(5m + 9n)\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to multiply the conjugate pairs:

  1. \((2x + 5)(2x - 5)\)

Step 1
Are the binomials conjugates?
\((2x+5)(2x-5)\)

It is the product of conjugates.
\(\begin{pmatrix} {\style{color:red}a}\; {\style{color:red}+}\; {\style{color:red}b} \\2x+5\end{pmatrix}\) \(\begin{pmatrix} {\style{color:red}a}\; {\style{color:red}-}\; {\style{color:red}b} \\2x-5\end{pmatrix}\)

Step 2
Square the first term, \(2x\).
\(\begin{array}{c} {\style{color:red}a} ^ {\style{color:red}2}\; {\style{color:red}-}\; {\style{color:red}b} ^ {\style{color:red}2} \\{(2x)}^2-\_\_\_\end{array}\)

Step 3
Square the last term, 5.
\(\begin{array}{c} {\style{color:red}a} ^ {\style{color:red}2}\; {\style{color:red}-}\; {\style{color:red}b} ^ {\style{color:red}2} \\{(2x)}^2-5^2\end{array}\)

Step 4
Simplify. The product is a difference of squares.
\(\begin{array}{c} {\style{color:red}a} ^ {\style{color:red}2}\; {\style{color:red}-}\; {\style{color:red}b} ^ {\style{color:red}2} \\{4x^2}-25 \end{array}\)

  1. \((5m-9n)(5m+9n)\)

Step 1
This fits the pattern of the Product of Conjugates.
\(\begin{pmatrix} {\style{color:red}a} {\style{color:red}-} {\style{color:red}b} \\5m-9n\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} {\style{color:red}a} {\style{color:red}+} {\style{color:red}b} \\5m+9n\end{pmatrix}\\\)

Step 2
Use the pattern.
\(\begin{array}{c} {\style{color:red}a} ^ {\style{color:red}2}\; {\style{color:red}-}\; {\style{color:red}b} ^ {\style{color:red}2} \\{(5m)}^2-{(9n)}^2\end{array}\)

Step 3
Simplify.
\(25m^2-81n^2\)

page.title: 6.2.5: Multiplying Polynomial Functions
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)


Student Activity

Use the following polynomial functions to complete the multiplication.

\(f(x) = 3x + 2b\)
\(g(x) = 3x - 2b\)
\(h(x) = 7x + 2\)
\(j(x) = 9x^2-12x+4\)

  1. \(f(x) \cdot g(x) =\) _______

ANSWER: \(9x^2-4b^2\)


  1. \(f(x) \cdot f(x) = \) _______

ANSWER: \(9x^2-12xb+4b^2\)


  1. \(h(x) \cdot j(x) = \) _______

ANSWER: \(63x^3-66x^2+4x+8\)


  1. \(h(x) \cdot h(x) =\) _______

ANSWER: \(49x^2+28x+4\)

page.title: 6.2.7: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
To help students’ understanding of key points from the lesson, discuss the following:

  • “Why are the properties of exponents important when multiplying polynomials?” (When multiplying polynomials, terms of different degrees are often multiplied together. The properties of exponents determine how this process goes.)
  • “How is the Distributive Property used to multiply polynomials?” (Each term in one polynomial is distributed through a second polynomial using multiplication. Like terms are combined to simplify the product.)
  • “How is Vertical Alignment used to multiply polynomials?” (Polynomials are written vertically in a traditional multiplication format. The individual products from the multiplication of each term are added together to find the final product.)
  • “How is the FOIL method used to multiply polynomials?” (The FOIL method is specifically used to multiply two binomials. A four-step process is used, first-outside-inside-last, to ensure that each term is multiplied together. Like terms are combined to simplify the product.)
  • “How is recognizing binomial squares and conjugate pairs helpful in polynomial multiplication?” (These two situations represent special cases of binomial multiplication in which the products fit very particular patterns. This helps us take a small shortcut in finding and organizing the final product of these binomials.)
